Problem:
Consider a complex function defined by \\( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} \\), where \\( \omega \\) is a constant and \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit. We inspect the effects on the function when it is subjected to a Fourier transformation, given by \\( F(z)(\xi) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{-i \xi t} z(t) \, dt \\).

If at some time \( t_1 \), a transformation defined by \( h(t) = t \cdot z(t) \) is applied to \( z(t) \) prior to the Fourier transformation, will the resulting \( F(h)(\xi) \) peak still primarily reflect the original \( \omega \)?
Explanation: The intervention with \( h(t) \) alters \( z(t) \) by multiplying it with time \( t \), which introduces additional frequency components due to the modulation. This results in the derivation of different spectral characteristics in \( F(h)(\xi) \), hence the peak frequency may shift or broaden, not reflecting the original \( \omega \) exclusively.
